tagDescription: 8 pages. A.L.S. dated at Stockton, Manitoba 8 November 1885. Describes his activities as farm labourer in Manitoba.

Royal North-West Mounted Police Report by Corporal D. Churchill. 1 page. A.L.S. dated at ''G Division. Edmonton. 1 April 1920. Corp. Churchill tells of the various prospecting parties that went up the South Nahanni between 1913 and 1916 and of the fate that befall them.
1 page. A.L.S. dated at Moosomin 30 September 1893.
4 pages. A.L.S. dated at Camp 4 Minot [Dakota]. 5 -7 August [1887?] Decides to go up to Moose Fountain and scout out the place for his father.

12 pages. A.L.S. dated at Cannington, Moose Mountain. 25 February 1888. Discusses house construction, comments on a letter in the Chronicle that denigrates the North West. Outlines some personal goods to bring from England and building materials and equipment that should be purchased in Ontario to save expense. Advises father to purchase only Massey Co. equipment. Gives a hint on packing of goods.

1 page. A.L.S. dated at Vancouver, B.C. 6 March 1921. Jack acknowledges receipt of part of the money he expected, claims it throws his original plans out of order but he is determined to leave for the north anyways.
6 pages. A.L.S. dated at Camp 4, Minot, Dakota. nd. [1887?] Describes life and wages on construction as railway is built into Montana along hanks of Missouri River.

6 pages. A.L.S. dated at Camp 4, Minot, Dakota. n.d.. [1887?] Relates what he knows of Cannington Manor and Moose Mountain Area. Mentions Captain Pierce. Continues to describe his life in railway construction camp in Montana and mentions strikes due to lack of food.
2 pages. A.L.S. dated at Vancouver, B.C. 5 November 1951. Jack gives Percy information on various members of the family and mentions his own situation.
1 page. A.L.S. dated 22 February 1921. Percy promises to send as much money as possible.
8 pages. A.L.B. dated at Stratherne, 2 August [1885?]. Anecdotes about prairie farmers and the wages they pay. Describes thrashing and harvesting operations. Tells of low wheat prices.
A scrap of paper outlining in figures the amount of cash needed for transportation to Canada.
a lithograph, n.d. entitled The Choor Mountains.
one photo of Cannington Manor, N.W.T.

8 pages. A.L.S. dated at Camp 4, Minot, Dakota. 28 July [1887?] Describes how difficult it would be for him to reach Moose Mountain at this time. Outlines wage situation and his work on the railway construction outfit in Montana. Offers advice on taking up a homestead. Mentions difference between Canadians and the English.

2 pages. A.L.S. dated at Stewart, B.C. 10 December 1920. Jack tells of impending oil rush to Fort Norman and his plans to stake an oil claim on his way up the Nahanni. He urges Percy to hurry the finalization of the estate sale as he is leaving on 24 January.
3 pages. A.L.S. dated at Cannington, Moose Mountain. Assiniboia. 29 October 1887. Pierce describes the land he has reserved for Stanier and urges them to settle nowhere else.
1 page. A.L.S. dated at Vancouver. 7 February 1921. Jack urges Percy to send balance of money by beginning of March.
4 pages. A.L.S. dated at Cannington, Moose Mountain. 18 January 1888. Describes house to be built and mentions cost. Encloses plan of house. Gives advice on buying livestock in Ontario.
List of the expenditures on permanent improvements at Uppington 1864-88. 4 pages.

4 pages. A.L.S. dated at Dakota, U.S.A. 1 May 1887. Describes his trekking down to get a job on St. Paul and Minneapolis Rwy. Comments on half-breeds he met. Describes life and wages on a railway.construction gang.
One itemized account of sale of all farm implements and livestock at Uppington 8-9 March 1888.
3 pages. A.L.S. dated at Cannington, Moose Mountain. 29 November 1887. Pierce specifies the sections of land that Stanier's son has filed for him and congratulates him.
2 pages. A.L.S. dated at Vancouver, B.C. 10 February 1921. Jack outlines his latest plans, recalls his hardship on trial of '98 and urges Percy to forward the money.
1 page. A.L.S. dated at Stewart, B.C. 26 December 1920. Jack asks again about the estate money and informs Percy of a few family matters.
Copy of Above.

Letter from the Dominion Lands Commission to Captain Pierce. 2 pages. Dated at Winnipeg 21 November 1887. The Lands Commission informs pierce of the necessity for a few adjustments in the lands reserved for Stanier due to his later arrival in Canada.
6 pages. A.L.S. dated at Stockton, Manitoba. 3 April 1886 . Outlines his activities, financial state and ideas on getting a homestead.

2 pages. A.L.S. dated at Cannington, Moose Mountain. 30 December 1887. Relates he has purchased a few implements, mentions names of couple of prospective emigrants and tells of the first fatality in Cannington.
7 pages. A.L.S. dated at Stockton, Manitoba 20 December 1885. Describes his activities as farm labourer and outlines hopes to buy his own homestead.

1 page. A.L.S. dated at Stewart B.C. 26 July 1920. Jack inquires concerning sale of English estate. Says he is working in a mine near Stewart but intends to go up the Nahanni soon as he gets the cash.
1 page. A.L.S. dated at Liverpool. 29 March 1888. Baker gives advice on meals plans on C.P.R. in Canada.
tagPerson: Baker, Archer, (European Traffic Agent of the C.P.R.)

tagDescription: 2 pages. A.L.S. dated at London, England. 20 October 1887. Evans (the C.P.R. agent in London) replies to a previous letter of Stanier, outlining passenger and freight rates between England and Moosomin, N.W.T.
2 pages. A.L.S. dated at Fort Simpson, Mackenzie River. N.W.T. 24 June 1921. Jack describes his trip to Fort Simpson and outlines his plans for the Nahanni Region.

3 pages. A.L.S. dated at Cannington, Moose Mountain, Assiniboia, 21 September 1887. Pierce informs Stanier that his son Jack has arrived and is impressed with the settlement. He outlines the terms for a homestead and urges Stanier to bring other families with him.

2 pages. A.L.S. dated at Fort Simpson, Mackenzie River. N.W.T. 13 February 1928. Jack describes his seven fears trapping and prospecting for the elusive yellow stuff. Excellent description of his trips up the S. Nahanni.
2 pages. A.L.S. dated at Vancouver, 15 January 1921. Jack outlines his plans for going into the Nahanni region and gives his opinion of other family members.
One itemized account of the sale of all household effects at Uppington 10-11 April 1888. 5 pages.
Two copies of account of the Auctioneers April 1888. 2 pages.

14 pages. A.L.S. dated at Cannington. 12 December 1887. Outlines cost of construction of house and purchase of implements. Describes his cutting and hauling logs for the house. Mentions the names of a few recent immigrants to Cannington.

16 pages. A.L.S. dated at Cannington, Moose Mountain. 14 November [1887?] Describes Captain Fierce and his family and the Captain's relations with Canadian government. Outlines grain, livestock and farm Implement prices. Describes type of house that can be erected, and describes the homestead site.

4 pages. A.L.S. dated at Cannington, Assiniboia. 20 March [1888?]. Gives advice on ship accommodation and train routes. Describes construction of house and mentions the cost of some other houses in Cannington including Captain Pierces. Tells of Pierce's first winter in North West.
1 page. A.L.S. dated at Beckenham, Kent. 2 January 1953. A letter of thanks for New Years greetings.

8 pages. A.L.S. dated at Cannington, Moose Mountain. 5 September 1887. Describes Cannington settlement, land conditions, prices and Captain Pierce. Outlines two possible homesteads for his father to purchase and equipment needed.
File copy of letter No. 16.
8 pages. A.L.S. dated at Stratherne, 28 June [1885?]. Describes his various experiences as a prairie farm labourer, and gives his estimation of the North West.
2 pages. A.L.S. dated at Victoria, B.C. 26 August 1940. Charlie tells of death of Edith and asks for a birth certificate from England for his brother George for Pension purposes.
2 pages. A.L.S. dated 24 January 1921. Percy outlines the difficulties in liquidating the estate and assures Jack of eventual payment of his money.
one photo of the Stanier Family Home

4 pages. A.L.S. dated at Cannington, Moose Mountain, Assiniboia. 21 June 1887. Pierce outlines the type and price of homesteads available at Cannington and the great benefits awaiting the emigrant who settles there.

3 pages. A.L.S. dated at Ragdon Church, Stretton Salop. 6 January 1886. Heynes outlines possibilities for settlement in state of Kansas, he names an English gentleman who owns land there and gives Stanier his (Heynes) own address in Kansas.
Photos and lithographs transferred to Picture Division, January 1972.
5 pages. A.L.S. dated at Montana. 12 August [1887?] Describes country he has to pass through to reach Moose Mountain. Relates what he has heard of Cannington Manor.
5 pages Cablegram dated at Stewart. B.C. 16 June 1920. First 4 pages are Commercial Cable Co. cover sheets. Stanier asks his brother to cable £200 soon as possible.

tagPerson: Thompson, F. S., (Agent of the Allan Line)
tagDescription: 1 page. A.L.S. dated at Liverpool. 3 February 1888. Thompson encloses lists and particulars re Atlantic sailings. [Lists not with this material]
Pieces of a torn cheque for £5 dated 16 December 1944 and endorsed by A. W. Sibley.

8 pages. A.L.S. dated at Stockton, Manitoba. 12 December [1886?] Describes farming conditions around Plum Creek, Manitoba, and Stockton Manitoba. Mentions grain and livestock prices and possible effects of Hudson's Bay road; coal deposits in Manitoba, and cutting wood in the bush.

4 pages. A.L.S. dated at R.R. No. 1, Manor. Saskatchewan. 5 December 1938. Edith tells of the weather and crops in their area and relates the deaths and whereabouts of a number of old Canningtonians including Jack Stanier.
1 page. A.L.S. dated at Liverpool. 8 February 1888. Information re rates for the sailing of the CIRCASSIAN.

8 pages. A.L.S. dated at Stockton, Manitoba. 10 October [1886?] Compares farming in Ontario to prairie farming, gives advice concerning starting a homestead in Manitoba. Mentions Hudsons Bay Route contracts.

4 pages. A.L.S. dated at Stewart, B.C. 30 August 1920. Thanks his brother for money and tells him of past year's experiences in Stewart. Again outlines his plans to go up the Nahanni for gold next year. Mentions he was up in Klondyke in '98.
1 page. A.L.S. dated at Liverpool. 28 March 1888. The list of the various members of the Stanier party and the cabins they will occupy on the CIRCASSIAN.
1 page. A.L.S. dated at Liverpool. 10 February 1888. More information re sailing and accommodation on CIRCASSIAN.
Two pages of the Nor-West Farmer and Manitoba Miller for August 1886. Two pages of letters to the editor re. immigration to the North West.

7 pages. A.L.S. dated at Stockton, Manitoba, 23 January 1887. Inquiries about father's emigration plans, mentions wheat prices, comments on discouraging reports of the prairies reaching England, tells of land sales.
1 page. A.L.S. dated at Edmonton, Alberta. 9 April 1920. Covering letter to above report listed as item 45.

10 pages. A.L.S. dated at Cannington. 9 February 1888. Describes the homestead acreage and Canadian land regulations. Discusses house construction and furnishings and various savings that can be made.

4 pages. A.L.S. dated at Prince Rupert,. B.C. 8 November 1919. Jack tells of the decline in shipyard industry at Vancouver due to end of war and outlines his plans to open up a store in Stewart because of news of the new ore strike there. He asks Percy, who is in England, to see if some money can be borrowed on the English estate to finance his proposed venture.
2 pages. A.L.S. dated at Grouard, Alberta [ca. 1920] Churchill answers Staniers questions regarding gold and Indians up the Nahanni River.
1 page. A.L.S. dated at Victoria, B.C. 28 August 1951. Beckton in reply to Percy's ad in the Victoria Daily Times gives information on old members of Stanier Family including Jack.

6 pages. A.L.S. dated at Cannington, Moose Mountain, N.W.T. 9 August 1887. Pierce outlines the great benefits of settling at Cannington and his hope for the future. He states the terms available for a homestead. He mentions the hopes placed on the Hudson's Bay Railway and urges Stanier to see Alexander Begg, CPR agent in London and arrange transport soon.

3 pages. A.L.S. dated at Cannington, Manor. Assiniboia, N.W. T. 21 January 1888. Pierce informs Stanier that he is unable to find a billet for Stanier's two sons but urges that they come out anyway. He urges not to bring their own piano out and suggest they purchase a certain stronger type which he specifies. He advises them of ways of bringing in their baggage duty free and tells them of the jobs which his two sons possess.
10 pages. A.L.S. dated a t Stockton, Manitoba. 15 August [1886?]. Describes crop conditions and the availability of good farm land,
1 page. A.L.S. dated at Cobble Hill, B.C. 29 August 1951. Tom gives Percy information on various living and dead members of the family.
